article.description: Texas kept alive the nation's longest home winning streak by getting to the free throw line when Oklahoma could not.
article.headline: Texas free throws key to Longhorn win
article.linkText: No. 3 Texas tops OU, keeps win streak alive
article.story:
AUSTIN, Texas (AP) -- Texas kept alive the nation's longest home
winning streak by getting to the free throw line when Oklahoma
could not.

The No. 3 Longhorns shot just 32 percent from the field but hit
26 of 31 free throws, including three by guard Nina Norman over the
final 22 seconds, to hold off No. 16 Oklahoma 63-58 Saturday.

Norman, a 52 percent free throw shooter this season, hit 11 of
12 against the Sooners and led Texas (14-1, 2-0 Big 12) with 17
points and 10 rebounds.

Texas has won 27 in a row at the Frank Erwin Center. The streak
is the nation's longest after Connecticut's 69-game streak was
snapped a week earlier by No. 1 Duke.

"We can make free throws in clutch situations," said Texas
coach Jody Conradt. "It was anybody's ballgame. Thankfully, we
made the plays down the stretch."

Texas held Oklahoma (11-2, 1-1) to 17 points in the first half
and led 39-25 in the second before the Sooners mounted a furious
comeback. A 10-0 Sooners run cut it to 47-45 before Texas pushed
the lead back to eight with 5:19 to play.

Maria Villarroel, who led all scorers with 18 points, hit a
3-pointer and scored seven straight to pull the Sooners within
59-58 with 1:10 left. Oklahoma had a chance to take its first lead
but Caton Hill missed a 6-footer that rolled around the rim before
falling out with 28 seconds left.

"That's one Caton usually makes," Oklahoma coach Sherri Coale
said. "(But) there were easily 35 plays before that that could
have changed the outcome of the game."

It was the plays after the miss that sealed it for Texas.

Center Stacy Stephens grabbed the rebound off Hill's miss and
was fouled. She hit the front end of a 1-and-1 and missed the
second, but Texas got the ball back when Oklahoma's Dionnah Jackson
knocked the rebound out of bounds.

Norman then went 3-of-4 from the line down the stretch to seal
it as the Sooners missed their last five shots.

"I was feeling pretty good," Norman said. "I looked at coach
and she said 'You're fine, you're fine.' I felt OK after that."

Both teams played rugged defense. Stephens finished with nine
points and 10 rebounds but played only 19 minutes because of foul
trouble. Her absence opened up the lane for the Sooners to mount
their second-half comeback.

"It was typical Texas-OU basketball right there," Stephens
said. "It came down to who wanted things more."

It was more about who got to the free throw line more often.
While Texas earned the win from the line, the Sooners went 8-of-9
and didn't attempt any free throws in the first half.

"I don't think I've ever coached a game where we didn't get to
the free throw line in an entire half," Coale said, obviously
frustrated that her team wasn't getting the calls.

Texas outrebounded Oklahoma 48-35 and earned the win without
it's best defensive stopper, junior forward Kala Bowers, who was
out sick with a virus.

Standout freshman Tiffany Jackson got her first start. She
scored the game's first basket and finished with eight points but
also had six turnovers.

The Longhorns also got a strong effort from reserve forward
Mercedes Williams, who finished with seven points and eight
rebounds in Bowers' absence.
